1.heading: Writing.

6.heading: Writing.
6.title: "Commercialism Taken Too Far"
6.author: by Stephen Hirsch.
notes: Byline is from Detroit Free Press; strip signed "Hersh."
Summary: Steven writes commercials, but letting Nike paint a swoosh on the house is too much.
Key words: Domiciliary advertising, logos, art, Pam, omelettes.

7.heading: Writing.
7.title: "Depends Who Wrote the Script"
7.author: D&R.
notes: Summary: If wrestling matches are a form of fiction, what if Hemingway were the writer?
Key words: The Undertaker, Hulk Hogan.

8.heading: Writing.
8.title: "Dogs Don't Lead Very Complicated Lives"
8.author: Mark O'Hare.
notes: Summary: Fergus writes in his diary.

10.heading: Writing.
10.title: "Group Writing"
10.author: by Scott Adams.
notes: Summary: Dilbert writes the word "the" on the flipchart, and the rest of the group voices its objections.
Date is that of publication in The Detroit News.

11.heading: Writing.
11.title: "The Handicap"
11.author: J
notes: Summary: The Worry Wart leaves the kitchen after making sandwiches, wishing he could write so he could leave a note saying he'd been there.

12.heading: Writing.
12.title: "He's Writing a Sniff-and-Tell Book"
12.author: Mike Peters.
notes: SUMMARY: Grimm finds more news about Carl the Wonder Poodle.

13.heading: Writing.
13.title: "How Do Ya Spell Moonyzipple?"
13.author: by Segar
13.appears_in: p. 7 of The Menomonee Falls Guardian, no. 1 (June 28, 1973).
notes: Summary: Popeye tries to write up his news story about an unconscious man found near the municipal building.

14.heading: Writing.

14.author: by Unger
14.appears_in: p. 75 in Battered Husbands (Redondo Beach, CA : H. Gregory Associates, 1991).
notes: Summary: A wife is talking to her prisoner husband while a guard listens.

15.heading: Writing.

notes: Summary: Tuck is thinking about writing an autobiography.

16.heading: Writing.
16.title: "I Wrote Some Stand-Up Material; You Want to Hear It?"

17.heading: Writing.
17.title: "If Zero Dies It Will Be All My Fault!"
17.author: Darrell McClure.
notes: Summary: The matron has written to the dog-ketchers to take Zero away, and even though it's winter Annie is talking about running away.

18.heading: Writing.
18.title: "I'm Writing a Letter to the Pope"
18.author: Copi
notes: Four tiers.

23.heading: Writing.
23.title: "The Major has a Large Nest Egg Twiggs Doesn't Know About"
23.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Amos chides Twiggs for making him, of a line of Shakespearean actors, accept money for his speeches to be used as a sleep-producing record; Twiggs reminds him that Shakespeare himself wrote for money, the best kind of applause.

24.heading: Writing.
24.title: "Mom! Motherhood is Not a Correspondence Course"

notes: Summary: Didn't I write you from every exotic post office on Earth?

25.heading: Writing.

27.heading: Writing.
27.title: "Pining Away for Kudzu Dubose"
27.author: Marlette.
notes: Summary: Ida Mae Wombat reads her essay about her Summer vacation, which included computer camp, selling dental floss door-to-door, rushing the stage when Leonard Nimoy appeared at an sf convention in Atlanta, and writing Kudzu's name in magic markers all over her loose-leaf notebook.

29.heading: Writing.
29.title: "The Pot Boils Over"
29.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos is writing a spring song at the piano, that will drown out Mendelssohn. Martha wants to know, given a world of atom bombs, cold war, hot war, reds, jets, taxes and tanks, if the vernal equinox has cracked his bell.
Key words: Musical composition, daffodils.

64.heading: The Writing of Comics.
64.title: "Contre le Scénario Normalisé : Réponses à 9e Art"
64.author: Benoît Peeters
64.appears_in: p. 88-90 in 9e art : Les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 4 (Jan. 1999).
notes: Begins: "La production du scénariste Benoît Peeters témoigne d'une volunté de se soustraire aux contraintes traditionnelles de la série. Nous lui avons posé quatre questions sur ce sujet, auxquelles il a bien volu répondre longuement par écrit."

English summary (from p. 143): "Down with Normalized Scripts! The scriptwriter Benoît Peeters functions outside of the traditional serial form in his partnerships with François Schuiten and Frédéric Boilet. He explains why and denounces certain of his colleagues who are, in part, responsible for the banalization of scripts."
